div1.ab: Mr. Alby, Manager of the Vice-Consulate of France in Freetown (Sierra-Leone) to Mr. Develle, Minister of Foreign Affairs. Paris.
div1.p: I had the honor to report to V.E. in a letter from the 12th of July, of the existence on the territory of Sierra Leone of an american mission that projects to grow its establishments into our new possessions of Sudan - Here is the complementary information that I could obtain on this subject.
"The American Sudan Mission" after unfortunate temptations.

A few years ago, there was founded in the "International Missionary Alliance" which has its headquarters in New-York. Its Superior Mr. E. Sampson, General Superintendent, has just made a trip around the world in the interest of the development of this association. He has not yet returned to New-York, but he assured me that he passed the Tonking where it is of question to establish a mission
The mission established in the Colony of Sierra-Leone is in very good terms with the Anglican Bishop of Freetown and the other religious sects that proliferate there. "The American Sudan Mission,"

still designed without this name to distinguish it from the other branches of "the international Missionary Alliance" counts twenty missionaries for this Colony; on this number, six are on leave in America, the other fourteen, are distributed, without the direction of Mr. H.W. Hubby, in the diverse establishments of Sierra Leone.

Three are in convalescence in Freetown, the others are in Mahera, in Magbele and in Magbeu-Kete, little towns or villages situated on the banks of the Rokelle River. Magbele indicated on the map under the name of Mabelin, and in the official

documents under the name of Magbelli, (A map of Sierra Leone and neighbouring Territories For use in Schools 1887 - 51 South Castle Street. Liverpool) counts, they say, 6,000 indigenous habitants, whom would be nearly three times more than any count of our villages of Guinée. - There is not a post office. - It is the limit of navigation in vapor on the river Rokell, that upstream from Magbele takes the name of Magbele.
There is thus one of these missionaries in Rokonson, or Kounson, a village near which is found a very important farm belonging to a
missionnary of another sect, named Mr. Johnston, one coffee, , and millet in rather large quantity.
The mission of Sierra Leone proposes to in the next season until of Niger, then to descend the river until , and even farther, founding stations there where this will be possible.
In its beginnings, about five or six years ago, the mission lost nearly all of its members by default of the experience of the country where it was searching to install itself; today it is more

satisfied with the obtained results. It expects to have next year a little steamer that will be charged with stocking it and facilitating its communications by the Rokell-the biggest difficulty being there, as in all of the colonies of the west coast of Africa, to procure the necessary supplies to those that can nourish themselves exclusively with rice or millet; furthermore, the unhealthy parties of this territory being those that neighbor the mouth of the rivers, as soon as one finds themself at the altitudes of one to two hundred meters, the climate there becomes perfectly supportable and just as healthy as elsewhere

under exceptional circumstances. These considerations encourage the "American Mission" to pursue its work of penetration in Sudan. Its members are people of a certain instruction that do topographic studies and possess information of which I hope to obtain the communication - it seems that the precited map is very inexact and it was given to me as an example of the distance of the route between Magbele and Magbeu Kète which is 22 miles and that of RouKonson to Magbeukète that measures around 60 miles toward the E.N-E - while the map gives this last distance
as sensibly shorter than the preceding.

To return to the "International Missionary Alliance", this society would count around 170. missionnaries, of which 20 in the mission of Sudan; 30 in the mission of the Congo, in the State Belgium, but near the french border, in Bouma and in Veva; 70 in the Indies; 4 in Palestine; 20/30 in China; some in South America.
The action of these missionaries consists, they say, in the example of work, the austerity of the customs, good behavior; their means of progress, outside of all political propaganda, are

agricultural installations, farms, cultures, foundation of families, good relations with the Indigenous, etc . . . On the side of this "American Soudan Mission" it would have existed until last year, on the base of Niger, the "English Sudan Mission" that tried to retake Niger in leaving Lagos. But this mission lead by Rév. Wilmot Brook, without the high direction of the Anglican Bishop Sierra Leone, was abandoned in 1892, following the death of Rév. W. Brook and the majority of his companions. One of them however, retourned to England and decided another Evangelic
Association to take the suite of this entreprise.
It is that who leads the "American Mission" to think that soon it will meet on the Niger with the "English Mission."

These different attempts of penetration of Sudan by foreigners, to which title that this be, appeared to be of the nature to interest Your Excellence and maybe you will judge Mr. Minister, that for lack of french agents in state of initiating the indigenous of these distant regions from our civilization, there could be place to interest to our cause or simply to favor those of
these Missionnaries that seem by their origin and the neutral character of their entreprise, the more capable of us render service, or at least to not harm us./.
div1.note: This guarantee does not me. In the foreign always seems .

It to know first if this american Sudan Mission is not
the English Soudan Mission
